title: Router Table - V0
text:
Purpose
I wanted to have a router table to have more control over my woodworking router and be able to quickly use it with minimal setup. Router tables are very simple in construction, so there are many different options when designing.

Restrictions
At the time, I didn’t have many woodworking tools but I had a CNC and a 3d printer.

Minimal cost
CNC cut wood only
3d printed hardware



Design goals

Adjustable fence
Dust extraction
Easy access to router

title: Router Table - V0
text:
Design Choices

Adjustable Fence
 The fence has replaceable front faces that slide open so I can tune the air flow for the dust extraction. These faces are adjusted by releasing the 3d printed knob(orange) on the back of the fence.

To whole fence can move forwards by adusting another 3d printed knob(blue) that engages a wedge in the 3d printed dovetail slot.
 The dovetail wedge has a bolt pressed into it so the knob can pull the wedge up, locking the wedge into the dovetail to lock the fence. The bolt is not shown here but extends up through the fence to the blue knob.


Dust extraction
 The vaccum adapter was kept simple, just a taper to match my vaccum hose. The airflow is is tuned by adjusting the width of the gap in the fence. The vaccum adapter also adds to the rigidity of the fence.


Replacement router plate mount
 The plate that came with my router didn’t not have apropriate mounting holes and had too large of an opening. I redesigned it to have a wider area that would easily index into the table and could be firmly mounted. Additional airflow holes were added to allow debris to not interfere with the cuts. This part was 3d printed out of ABS, with an option for replaceable zero clearance insert.


CNC box joint plywood
The box construction is entirely CNC cut and tightly fits together. The joints are fastened together only with screws temporarily(for 1 year).

title: Router Table - V0
text:
Problems

Lack of rigidity
Likely due to the non-glued joints and difficulties with tightening dovetail.


Lack of flatness
The CNC cut joints all protruded past the top surface requiring them to be sanded down, however the veneer is very thin and I often sanded through resulting in even more inconsistencies.


Too tall
The router table needed to be tall enough to contain the full travel of the router but is also table mounted so is too tall for easy use.


Difficult to adjust
The fence is difficult to do micro-adjustments, likely due to the stick-slip nature of the ABS dovetail surfaces.


Non-square fence
The fence would go out of alignment whenever it was moved, likely due to the lack of rigidity in the fence.


No miter slot
Without a miter slot I was unable to securely move parts across the router bit, which led to many damaged parts where the bit grabbed the part.

title: Router Table - V0
text:
Next Version
I want to incorporate the router table into my table saw table area. So mounting features for the router table so it can be aligned perfectly flush with adjoining tables will be crucial so to not jam movement across the table surface.
I think Mattias’ tilting router lift will dictace the whole mount and bottom assembly.
The fence needs to be much more rigid, ideally a monolithic part with many methods for micro-adjustments.
A miter slot would allow for many ways to run the move the parts across the bit, giving me access to many different jig options.

title: 3d printed Capsule Packer
text:
Usage
This design allows for the split capsules to be added to the frame. The capsules are level with the upper frame so materials can placed on top and directed into the capsules. After filling and removing the excess material the upper frame can be removed to press the capsules so they are proud of the upper frame surfrace. Then capsules can be capped and removed from the frame.



Split capsules added to frame

title: 3d printed Capsule Packer
text:
Problems with this design

Limited number of capsules at a time.
No integrated area to pressing capsules proud of uppper frame

I have to find a flat area to gently press the capsules out

Capsules must be split and capped individually by hand

text:

Way to semi-automate the aligning of capsules into a grid
Remove caps all at once with jig
Integrate a way of pressing the capsules proud of the upper frame once they are filled
Apply all caps at once with a jig

title: Trim Router Jig - Tongue and Groove Jointer
text:
Usage
When the jig is attached to the router it must be aligned so the runner is the correct distance from the router bit. I’m using a 1/4” bit so runner and gap are also 1/4” so the tongues and grooves fit perfectly.

Adjustment
By loosening the bolts that hold the jig to the router, the gap between the runner and bit can be adjusted. A perfect fit will need to also allow for a thin layer of glue.

title: Toolpost Grinder - Trim Router
text:
Toolpost grinders allow for machining of harder materials and can produce a better surface finish for parts. My mini lathe has lack of rigidity due to it’s total size/weight, so a grinding will allow much higher quality surface finishes.

The 3d printed mount was designed using a 3d model of my mini lathe. The mount positions the spindle of the router to be vertically aligned to the lathe spindle. This will allow to the abrasive wheel to have good contact at the center, so I can grind points on the lathe.

title: ESP8266-12F Breakout Board
text:
Programming/UART
The ESP8266 comes with a basic firmware that allows for a new firmware to be uploaded over UART. This allows for the USB to be able to upload firmware without a specific program upload option like JTAG.

title: ESP8266-12F Breakout Board
text:
Flashing firmware
Can be done in console using esptool.
pip install esptool
esptool.py --port /dev/ttyUSB0 --baud 115200 write_flash -fm dout 0x00000 <firmware.bin>
Can also be done in the Arduino dev environment, which is also an easy way to compile the code to *.bin. Arduino also has a cli tool, arduino-cli that can invoke all the same tools as the GUI.

title: Rong Fu 31
text:
RF31 3d model


I received this mill from a friend of a friend as they were unable to store it any longer. As far as I could tell it was never used and still had the original thick waxy oil used when shipping these mills from Asia. I had to dissasemble it to move it into my shop so I know that I was the first to even do any basic maintanace, because every part I needed to remove would crack the paint at the joint.
The RF31 is a round column mill that is typcally called a mill/drill which helps indicate it’s general use as a drill press, with a secondard use as a lightweight milling machine. I have learned with my steady upgrades in milling machine sizes that weight is king in nearly every possible way when it comes to rigidity and percision. This is the 3rd milling machine I have owned, the other two being <150lbs each. The RF31 is ~600lbs and the rigidity improvements when compared to the lighter machines is drastic.

Upgrades

Digital Read Out(DRO)
 I was able to find a cheap DRO on AliExpress that seemed to have the correct buttons and screen I wanted. From my research on DRO’s they are usually packaged to match your specific mill, instead I just asked the supplier to give me 3 scales with the correct travel distances from the manual. All aspects of the DRO installation are custom and don’t somewhat on the fly, so I assumed I could just attach it somehow if I got the correct size.

title: Max Teicheira
text:
I am an electrical engineering student at University of California, Santa Cruz working at the Radiological Insturments Laboratory(RIL). My research for RIL focuses on positon emission tomography(PET) imaging using edge-on cross-strip CZT.
I will complete my undergraduate degree in electrical engineering in 2025, then start my PhD immediately to continue my research.
I am also a part-time employee at Slugworks, a makerspace located in Baskin Engineering at UCSC.
You can find a list of my projects here. I write on random topics related to tools and making – look through my notebook here.
